docs.lead_paragraph: As they left Washington this weekend for the election break, Congressional Republicans were either muttering that President Clinton had once again taken them to the cleaners or defending their retreat in the last-minute budget showdown. Democrats heading for the airport were laughing, joking and enjoying the opposition's discomfort. This picture of partisan triumph and unity has momentarily obscured the President's odd relationship with his fellow Democrats on Capitol Hill. The party's Congressional leaders now stand in front of what looks to be an impressively united phalanx of support for Mr. Clinton against impeachment-minded Republicans.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Alonzo L Hamby, teacher of American history at Ohio University, contends that Democratic Congressional leaders seem to be united in their support of Pres Clinton and in their opposition to impeachment-minded Republicans; maintains that there is softness to their backing; asserts that lack of trust has existed between Democratic Presidents and Congressional Democrats since Pres Franklin D Roosevelt in 1938; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Stocks Decline Slightly After Advancing for 7 Days Stock prices retreated yesterday, breaking a run of seven advances, the longest in 16 months. No particular news seemed to account for the downturn, though the procession of quarterly earnings reports and company projections of weaker results again claimed casualties. Wall Street's victory parade for the New York Yankees was said to have held down midday volume.

docs.lead_paragraph: Frustrated by what he called a lack of attention to his gubernatorial campaign, Peter F. Vallone said yesterday that the public should be taking his proposals more seriously and pressuring Gov. George E. Pataki to debate him. In an hourlong interview with editors and reporters at The New York Times, Mr. Vallone, who is the Democratic gubernatorial nominee and the Speaker of the New York City Council, spent considerably more time lashing out at Mr. Pataki than discussing his own platform. He angrily questioned why the Republican Governor had remained popular despite increasing the state's debt, vetoing spending on education and failing to reform the state's campaign finance system.

headline.main: Vallone Calls Pataki Elusive, and Wants His Day on the Dais

docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton Administration moved today to clarify the rights of hundreds of thousands of elderly Medicare beneficiaries being dropped from health maintenance organizations, and it threatened to impose fines on insurance companies that refuse to sell them coverage. But under pressure from insurance companies, the Administration backed away from an earlier interpretation of Federal law that would have granted similar protections to people under age 65 who qualify for Medicare because of disabilities. Some insurers had threatened to sue the Government if it pressed this reading of the law.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearing completion on East 86th Street, the 246-unit Ventura is the newest addition to the Upper East Side streetscape, and the first luxury rental designed to attract young professionals in six years along the 16-block stretch from 80th to 96th Streets. Most of the apartments -- 83 percent -- in the 22-story building at 240 East 86th Street, which is to be completed in April, will be studios and one-bedroom units of 500 to 900 square feet. The remaining apartments will have two bedrooms and 1,000 to 1,300 square feet. There will also be 40,000 square feet of retail space.

headline.main: Residential Real Estate; New Tower for Young Professionals on East Side

docs.lead_paragraph: On a recent evening, a crowd of elegantly dressed people, many of them Democrats, gathered at the Hilton Hotel in Manhattan to honor a Brooklyn housing group founded by one of the state's most famous liberals, Senator Robert F. Kennedy. And there, seated near the front, was an unlikely guest of honor: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the three-term Republican running hard for a fourth. Mr. D'Amato had just completed another day of attacking his Democratic challenger, Representative Charles E. Schumer, as being a Brooklyn liberal. But this evening, the Senator accepted an award for his work on behalf of the nonpartisan group, the Bedford Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation, and then started into a speech peppered with phrases Mr. Kennedy would have appreciated.

headline.main: A Conservative, D'Amato Learned to Adapt
headline.kicker: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: RACE FOR THE SENATE -- THE INCUMBENT

docs.abstract: Analysis of Sen Alfonse M D'Amato's campaign to turn back Democratic challenger, Repr Charles E Schumer; finds that D'Amato, three-term Republican running hard for a fourth, is seen dancing away, in his campaign, from a Republican Party that seems anathema to many New Yorkers; but a review of D'Amato's most recent term shows that, for all his shifting on the edges, he remains a fundamentally conservative politician--among most conservative senators New York State has had since World War II; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The city began with the river. As the broad and occasionally unruly Ohio flows southwest from Pittsburgh toward its rendezvous with the Mississippi, it is interrupted here by rapids. In 1778, that barrier prompted George Rogers Clark, a young frontiersman from Virginia, to pause on his trip west and establish a settlement that eventually grew into this, the first metropolis west of the Alleghenies.

headline.main: Foot in the North, Heart in the South

docs.abstract: R W Apple Jr On the Road article about Louisville, Ky, which began in 1778 when George Rogers Clark paused at rapids of Ohio River before pushing on into wilderness; Clark returned to live out his last years at his sister's house, Locust Grove, now restored; other handsome mementos of city's early years, latter-day history and arts attractions noted; photos; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: H. Richard Nesson, the former president of Brigham and Women's Hospital, one of the nation's leading teaching hospitals, and a pioneer in hospital management in the new era of health maintenance organizations, died Oct. 18 in Boston. He was 66. Mr. Nesson suffered a heart attack while exercising, said the hospital's current president, Jeffrey Otten. Though retired from Brigham and Women's since 1997, Dr. Nesson remained a high-profile figure in Boston health care until his death. Last week, for example, he announced the creation of a program at a health center to give women without health insurance access to cancer tests.

headline.main: Richard Nesson, 66, Ex-President Of Teaching Hospital in Boston

docs.lead_paragraph: The two camps in the Connecticut governor's race set out today on very different paths to getting out the vote, with Democrats focusing on their traditional supporters by planning rallies featuring the Rev. Jesse Jackson, while Republicans began broadcasting television advertisements aimed across party lines. Mr. Jackson plans four appearances in the state's urban areas on Tuesday, a week before Election Day. His visit will culminate with a revival service that night at an African Methodist Episcopal church in New Haven near Yale University.

headline.main: Both Rowland and Kennelly Pressing to Get Out the Vote

docs.abstract: Two camps in Connecticut governor's race set out on very different paths to getting out vote, with Democrats focusing on their traditional supporters by planning rallies featuring Rev Jesse Jackson, while Republicans begin broadcasting television advertisements aimed across party lines; public opinion polls show Gov John G Rowland far ahead of his Democratic opponent Repr Barbara Kennelly (M)
